lotDescription.value: Eva Histia (<ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo, 1914-2005). Pair of <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> lamps, n.d. Each signed "E. Histia <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> New Mex,"on underside. A delightful and functional pair of <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> lamps handmade and painted by <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> artist Eva Histia. Each in the form of an olla, the lamps are painted with traditional designs of birds and flowers surrounded by geometric motifs, all in black and orange on a creamy beige ground and flanked by a pair of twisted handles. Each fitted with a custom cloth lamp shade and ready for use! Size without shade (both the same): 11.25" W x 13.25" H (28.6 cm x 33.7 cm); with shade (both the same): 18" W x 25" H (45.7 cm x 63.5 cm) Eva Histia (1914-2005) was a member of the Roadrunner Clan at <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo. She was the daughter of Helice Vallo and mother of Hilda Antonio, Rose Torivio, and Ida Ortiz. She was the grandmother of Mary J. Garcia and Lavine Torivio. Eva was an active potter as early as 1922 and continued until around 1990. lotDescription.value: Both pieces are in good condition with wear commensurate with age. The pot measures approximately 5D x 4H. The (2pc) Native American <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> <ais-highlight-0000000000>Pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> set features two exquisite pieces that reflect the richartistic heritage of the <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo, known for their exceptional <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> skills. Each piece in this set is handcrafted from local clay, then meticulously painted with intricate designs using natural pigments. 1. <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pot 1: This pot showcases traditional <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> geometric patterns, including fine lines, triangles, and stepped motifs. The high level of detail andprecision in the designs highlights the potter’s skill and dedication to maintaining cultural traditions. The white and black color scheme is characteristic of <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000>, symbolizing harmony and balance. 2. <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pot 2: The second pot in the set features more complex designs, possibly incorporating symbolic elements such as rain, clouds, and kiva steps, which are central to <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> cosmology. lotTitle.value: <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> <ais-highlight-0000000000>Pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> Lamps w/ Birds by Eva Histia

lotDescription.value: Eva Histia (<ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo, 1914-2005). Pair of <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> lamps, n.d. Each signed "E. Histia <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> New Mex,"on underside. A delightful and functional pair of <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> lamps handmade and painted by <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> artist Eva Histia. Each in the form of an olla, the lamps are painted with traditional designs of birds and flowers surrounded by geometric motifs, all in black and orange on a creamy beige ground and flanked by a pair of twisted handles. Each fitted with a custom cloth lamp shade and ready for use! Size without shade (both the same): 11.25" W x 13.25" H (28.6 cm x 33.7 cm); with shade (both the same): 18" W x 25" H (45.7 cm x 63.5 cm) Eva Histia (1914-2005) was a member of the Roadrunner Clan at <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo. She was the daughter of Helice Vallo and mother of Hilda Antonio, Rose Torivio, and Ida Ortiz. She was the grandmother of Mary J. Garcia and Lavine Torivio. Eva was an active potter as early as 1922 and continued until around 1990. lotDescription.value: Franklin Peters <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> <ais-highlight-0000000000>Pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> Bowl. Signed on bottom Franklin Peters / Huwaka / <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000>, NM. Franklin Peters was born into the Sky Clan on <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo. He learned the art of <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> making as he grew up surrounded by some of <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000>’s most well known potters: Ella Peters (his mother), Florence Aragon, Rachel Aragon, Phyllis Juanico, Dorothy Torivio, Wilfred Garcia, Frederica Antonio, and Barbara and Joseph Cerno. In 2011 Franklin was honored with the 2011 Rollin and Mary Ella King Native Artist Fellowship at the School for Advanced Research in Santa Fe. Keywords: Native American, Indian; Ref: BD1700

lotDescription.value: Native American, Southwestern United States, New Mexico, <ais-highlight-0000000000>Acoma</ais-highlight-0000000000> Pueblo, ca. late 20th century CE. A set of 5 hand-built <ais-highlight-0000000000>pottery</ais-highlight-0000000000> jars, each with a unique motif. Three of the vessels are presented in redware while the remaining 2 exhibit white grounds, each with dense decorative motifs in vibrant pigments. The largest is of the distinct San Juan Revival type. Size of largest: 4.8" W x 3.4" H (12.2 cm x 8.6 cm) Provenance: private Thornton, Colorado, USA collection All items legal to buy/sell under U.S. Statute covering cultural patrimony Code 2600, CHAPTER 14, and are guaranteed to be as described or your money back. A Certificate of Authenticity will accompany all winning bids. We ship worldwide and handle all shipping in-house for your convenience. #182912
